subject: Re: [junit] Re: Running a precondition before all tests
msgSnippet: ... I don t believe there is disagreement here, because nowhere did I write that Michael was doing something completely wrong . He asked, Is there a better
messageBody:
>So said Leonardo Abreu de Barros on 2003-07-15 --------------------
>Hi J.B.,
>
>I'm sorry to disagree with you, but I don't think what Michael is
>doing is completely wrong.

I don't believe there is disagreement here, because nowhere did I write that Michael was doing something "completely wrong". He asked, "Is there a better way?" I offered one.

Not all opinions need to be so polarizing.

>I understand that the framework offers us
>a lot of possibilities, and it's up to us to choose what's the best
>way to use it, according to our needs and purposes. I think all
>approaches have its pros and cons; for example, the approach he's
>using, of running batch tests starting with "Test", has the problem
>of not selecting a particular set of tests to run each time, but he
>has the benefit of not worrying about anything except his unit tests.

He is changing the names of tests by hand to group tests together. JUnit already has a natural way to group tests together that does not require this manual intervention. I think we can all agree that maintaining test suites in this way -- by hand -- is only a short-term solution (on the order of minutes). If a test suite needs to survive more than a few minutes, the most effective way to build the suite is by building a TestSuite object somehow.

>The suite approach, as you suggests, has a pro of grouping tests, but
>has also a con of hard-coding in a class which tests should be run.
>This is related to the problem I have, of running a piece of code
>somewhere before all tests.

Your problem is easy to solve, too: TestSetup. Or GSBase's OrderedTestSuite. Or your own custom TestRunner (the best solution) which runs your piece of code first, then the test suite. Any of those would work.

>If I've said something wrong, feel free to correct me, I'm always
>ready to learn.

As am I.
